Abstract: This study explores the intricate relationships between the structural and functional aspects of plant forms, revealing a complex interplay of biomechanical principles. Through a comprehensive analysis of plant morphology and anatomy, we demonstrate the existence of self-similar patterns and bilayer structures that optimize plant performance. The slender body shape of plants is shown to be a result of evolutionary adaptations that minimize water loss and maximize photosynthetic efficiency. Our research highlights the significance of structure-function relationships in plant biology, demonstrating that the intricate design of plant forms is a testament to the power of biological design. These findings have implications for our understanding of plant development and evolution.
